CatDescriptText: George Allen, laborer, North Side and Jacqueline Seay, housewife, Fifth Ward, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up series published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 20, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think that Negroes today, in Pittsburgh, are prone to follow Negro leadership in politics or do they consider it ineffective?  What do you think about their attitude nationally?"  George Allen's answer reads: "We tend to follow Negro leadership, but are getting no results."  Jacqueline Seay's answer reads: "I think they will follow their leadership if they will only go down and register...Generally speaking those registered Negro voters do...Yes, I think Negroes follow their national leaders."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of George Allen wearing light colored jacket and hat, standing on Wood Street with Raab Clothes and Dimling's Candy in background, Downtown; Portrait of Jacqueline Seay wearing light colored coat, standing on Wood Street with Raab Clothes sign in background, Downtown
